title: A Map Shows How Well Towns Fix Bumpy Roads
summary: In England, a new map helps drivers see how well their local towns are fixing potholes, which are holes in the roads. The government uses a traffic light system: red means the town is not doing well, amber means they are trying but need to do better, and green means they are doing a good job. Thirteen towns got a red rating, including Derbyshire, which had many potholes. Towns with red ratings will get extra money to help fix roads faster. The government gave Â£7.3 billion to fix roads over four years. Potholes can damage cars and cause accidents, costing drivers money for repairs. The map encourages towns to use money wisely to keep roads safe.

background_read: In England, roads sometimes get holes called potholes from weather and heavy use. These can be dangerous for drivers and expensive to fix. The government wants to help towns repair roads better so everyone can travel safely. A map with colors helps people see which towns are doing a good job and which need help.
Article_Structure: WHO: Drivers and local towns in England
WHAT: A map rates how well towns fix potholes using a traffic light system
WHY: To make roads safer and encourage towns to use money wisely for repairs

perspectives.description: The government wants to improve roads by rating towns and giving extra money to those struggling.
